questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion in India?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) in India is rickets.

The most common cause of true CPD in developing countries is vitamin D deficiency and rickets. In developed countries, it is trauma to the pelvis. It occurs due to pelvic dystocia (larger fetus and smaller pelvis).

Relative CPD is the most common type of CPD. It is caused due to fetal malposition (occipitoposterior position/brow presentation).

questions.text: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a term primigravida in labor. You find that the contractions are uncoordinated and the frequency is about 8 contractions every 10 minutes. Which of the following is incorrect regarding your finding?

choices.text: It is common in nulliparous labour
Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.solution:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is not beneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus.

Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction):

  • The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes)
  • Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated
  • The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy is adopted
  • It is more common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended.

Hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

  • Uterine contractions are inadequate
  • It is associated with early active phase
  • It is more common in nulliparous females.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patient is sedated with morphine.

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in prolonged latent phase.

There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable over the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed a large uterine wall defect. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. Maternal tachycardia is seen in this condition.

Clinical features of uterine rupture:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia/absent fetal heart sounds
  • Hypotension
  • Abdominal tenderness
  • Palpable fetal parts on per abdomen examination
  • Bandl’s ring
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 

Common causes of uterine rupture are previous caesarean delivery, myomectomy, silent rupture (in previous pregnancy), excess use of oxytocin, grand multipara, uterine overdistension, obstructed labour, difficult forceps delivery, placenta percreta

questions.text: A young primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation came with complaints of decreased perception of fetal movements for the past 2 days. NST is non-reactive and on ultrasound fetal cardiac activity is absent. What will be the best management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). The best management for such cases at 36 weeks is waiting for spontaneous expulsion.

Forceps extraction is only necessary if spontaneous expulsion doesn't take place. 

Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is not done due to the risk of infections. Cesarean section is avoided as far as possible in case of fetal death.

Waiting till term is not recommended in cases of uterine infections, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and psychological upset.

questions.text: A G2P1L0 woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation for a routine visit. She mentions that she has a history of prior stillbirth at 37 weeks. What is the best time for delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best time for elective delivery in patients with a history of previous stillbirth is 39 weeks, either by induction or cesarean section.

The recommendations for the management of subsequent pregnancy after stillbirth is as follows:

  • Ultrasonographic screening for fetal growth restriction after 28 weeks
  • Kick counts starting from 28 weeks of gestation
  • Antepartum fetal surveillance starting at 32 weeks or 1-2 weeks earlier than prior stillbirth
  • Support and reassurance

Labor induction is suitable in such cases. Cesarean delivery is done for those with a contraindication to induction.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
The best management in the given clinical scenario is cesarean section.

Obstructive labor management involves administering intravenous fluids to correct dehydration, providing antibiotics to prevent infection, and promptly performing a cesarean section to relieve the obstruction. If the fetus is alive, an immediate cesarean section is typically performed. Management of obstructed labor never involves a wait-and-watch approach or augmenting with oxytocin.

Clinical features of obstructed labor include maternal exhaustion, dehydration, tachycardia, tachypnea, genital sepsis, postpartum hemorrhage, and shock.
On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender and tonically contracted. The lower uterine segment is thin and stretched. A groove/depression is felt between the upper uterine segment and the lower uterine segment. This is called a Bandls ring.

Complications of obstructed labor include rupture of the uterus and vesicovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. 

Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

 

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that the cord is prolapsed. What should be the next immediate step of management?

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.solution:
In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in an exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh.

Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performing the procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measures involve:

  • Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through the vagina
  • Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chest position
  • Filling the bladder with 500–700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method)

After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Such attempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes, leading to cord prolapse.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: A 26-year-old term primigravida presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. On examination, uterus corresponds to term and head of the fetus is non-engaged.  What is the most common cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of non-engagement at term in a primigravida is deflexed head followed by cephalopelvic disproportion.

Non-engagement at the onset of active phase of labour is a risk factor for caesarean section.

The problems of prolonged labour are that the woman is exposed to high risk of infection, ketosis and obstructed labour while the fetus faces the danger of asphyxia and infection.

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a cardinal movement occurring during labor?
questions.solution:
Asynclitism is not a cardinal movement during labor.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder. This causes the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labor. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis. 

Asynclitism can be of 2 types:

  • When the sagittal suture lies anteriorly, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism.
  • When the sagittal suture lies posteriorly, the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is brought to the labour room in the latent phase of labor. How long will you wait till you declare her latent phase to be prolonged?
questions.solution:
Latent phase is said to be prolonged in a primigravida if it lasts for more than 20 hours.

Friedman defined prolonged latent phase as:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase

questions.text: All of the following findings are seen in the partogram of a patient except:
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hour, arrest of descent for >1 hour and a fall in fetal heart rate suggestive of fetal distress. 

These are characteristic findings of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents with labour pains. At 39 weeks of gestation, she was diagnosed with prolonged phase of labour. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Excessive sedation can prolong this phase

questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest that the patient is in latent phase of labor. Latent phase is said to be prolonged if it is:

  • >20 h in nullipara
  • >14 h in multipara

Causes of prolonged latent phase:

  • Excessive sedation/epidural analgesia
  • Poor cervical conditions (thick, uneffaced)
  • False labour (most common cause in multipara)

Friedman's curve is used in the diagnosis of prolonged labour. It is the sigmoid curve plotting the pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phase of normal labour.

Management includes morphine administration, rest and oxytocin stimulation.

questions.text: Protracted active phase dilatation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilatation is _____.
questions.solution:
Protracted active phase dilatation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilatation is less than 1.5 cm/hour. 

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: Which among the following is false with respect to active phase of labor?

choices.text: The minimum rate of cervical dilatation is 1.2cm/hr in nullipara
Arrest of dilatation is cessation of dilatation for >2 hours
Arrest of descent is cessation of descent for >1 hour
Poor cervical dilatation causes prolonged active phase

questions.solution:
Poor cervical dilatation causes a prolonged latent phase.

Arrest of cervical dilatation is defined as the lack of cervical dilatation for ≥ 2 hours during the active phase of labour.

According to the Obstetric Care Consensus Committee, when cervical dilatation has reached ≥ 6 cm with ruptured membranes, and there is no cervical change despite 4 hours of adequate uterine contractions or 6 hours of inadequate contractions, a cesarean delivery is warranted.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: Protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is ______
questions.solution:
The protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is less than 1 cm/hour.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

questions.text: A multigravida is posted for C-section due to arrest of descent in labor. It is defined as no descent for ______
questions.solution:
Arrest of descent in labor in a multigravida is no descent for more than 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor
